title: Renée Zellweger reveals her Judy costumes were designed so she 'couldn't move'
text:
She has been blazing the promo trail with her new movie Judy.

And Renée Zellweger was revealing all about the Judy Garland biopic during her appearance on Friday night's The Graham Norton Show.

The Bridget Jones' Diary actress, 50, candidly discussed her costumes in the movie, as she revealed she was sewn into her gowns to the point of not being able to move so as to mimic The Wizard Of Oz legend's slouching pose.

Open and honest: Renée Zellweger was revealing all about the Judy Garland biopic during her appearance on Friday night's The Graham Norton Show

Renée has taken on the role of Judy in one of the very first biopics about her turbulent life, and is centred around a series of shows she performed in 1969, just months before her death.

In the movie, which was released in the UK on Tuesday, she has won praise for her portrayal of the icon yet admitted it was hard work perfecting the talent.

Speaking about her costume, she said: 'Judy slouched a little and the dresses were made so that I couldn't have stood any other way. I was literally sewn into them.

'It was a great reminder during the day if you got lazy because you had no option but to stand like her. The sequins were very strict!'

Uncanny: Renee (left) is getting rave reviews and Oscar buzz for her portrayal of Judy Garland (right) in the film, based on Peter Quilter’s musical play End Of The Rainbow

The movie has sparked controversy due to the fact Judy's family, including her actress daughter Liza Minelli, have turned their back on the movie.

Despite this, Renée said: 'It's not depressing and you can't help but empathise with her. She's not tragic at all because she didn't quit. She's heroic.'

She was appearing on the show alongside journalist Louis Theroux, who joked: 'I think I'd have made a documentary about her and I would probably have ended up being her 6th husband!''

Judy's children have said they have no plans to see the film, and there has been no involvement from the Garland estate before or during production.

That was then: Renée said: 'It's not depressing and you can't help but empathise with her. She's not tragic at all because she didn't quit. She's heroic'

But despite this Renée said she hopes they will eventually see the film in a positive light, telling Lorraine: 'I do know that representatives of the family and estate have seen the film and that makes me smile.

'It's an emotional, a private and complicated thing, but my hope is that it will be recognised as this expression of affection and a proclamation of her importance.'

Judy's oldest daughter Liza had previously denounced the film and confirmed that she was not consulted about production.

She wrote on Facebook: 'I have never met nor spoken to Renee Zellweger. I don’t know how these stories get started, but I do not approve nor sanction the upcoming film about Judy Garland in any way. Any reports to the contrary are 100% Fiction.'

During the interview, Renée also spoke to Lorraine about how she mimicked Judy's incredible singing voice by listening to endless recordings of her performances.

She said: '[Judy] had this gift from the heavens which is in-imitable, I took that out of the equation and tried to familiarise myself with her style.

'I just kind of went from there and then it's just joy because that music is so wonderful.'

Hitting out: Judy's oldest daughter Liza (right with her siblings Lorna Luft and Joey Luft) had previously denounced the film and confirmed that she was not consulted about production

Renée also spent several hours in the makeup chair each day as a prosthetic nose and facial elements were used to transform her into The Wizard Of Oz actress.

Explaining the transformation she said: 'We pared it down and got better at it as it went along, it took about 90 minutes.

'Those guys were fantastic it was rare that it didn't go well, it was the contact lenses that was the most interesting, I'm wearing 20 peoples' jobs at any one time, everything is a shared process.'

Also on Graham Norton was Wham star Andrew Ridgeley, who was discussing his book Wham. George And Me.

Talking about his late bandmate, George Michael, he says: 'It seemed there was negativity after his death that threatened to overshadow his legacy, so I wanted to shift the perspective back on to the glory days and what was vibrant and exuberant about George’s life.'

Asked how he felt about Wham's fleeting success, he said: 'It all happened so quickly, and the success took us by surprise, but it had a finite lifespan.'

In regards to George's continual success, he said: 'I was never jealous of my best friend, but I was envious of his talent. I had achieved my ambition of being in a band and playing live and I wanted him to go on and realise his talent as much as he did.”

Talking about George’s legacy, he says: 'Personally, it’s our friendship – it will endure, it is eternal. For everyone else, he was an exceptional vocalist and songwriter. He was brilliant.'

The Graham Norton Show, BBC One, Friday 4th October 10.35pm.
